Morning Yvonne and everyone, I can identity wihh everything u are saying, I am 12 months post diagnosis and 10 months post op and I am no where near as fit and able physically, mentally or emotionally as I was a year ago . I am frustrated massively with the fatigue and the impact it has, my house is a mess i just can't manage what I used to. The hardest part of my recovery is coming to terms with just how much I have been forced to change, how many compromise s I have to make and coming to terms with my new limitations. I Intrepid sums it up very well. We are changed but we have survived We are changed but are alive. I am being bulldozed in to taking on more at work, more hours, responsibility more hassle! All that the folks at the meeting could see was the old ME and were stunned that I didn't want to take on this extra work! I could do withnthe extra money God only knows how hard it is to manage, but the emotional and physical cost is too high and its impacting on my precious time with my daughter. So my current battle is not only for me to accept the new ME but the folks around me to accept and understand too. So with Intrepids words in mind, I am going to take out the But.... I am changed I survived I am changed I am alive Love and God's blessing to u all x

Posts.Title: Does anyone have advice?

Posts.Content: Hi Mum of two, sounds like a melt down is just what you needed to relieve the stress of it all.  I have had a few of those myself and I am still waiting for my mx.   Also an f cup and have been told its a big op and will be a difficult recon.      Agree with aroma mum   talking about it does help and doing something which requires minimal effort like having a friend round who will make the tea and talk about normal things other than the cancer as well!    Also, having a good old cry and rant and moan to let the emotions out has worked for me!  I had a good cry last night - on my ex's shoulder, he doesn't do emotions either but he listened and didn't mind his t-shirt getting wet!   After my previous 2 ops  I told everyone I was ignoring the house work,  but I wanted to do as much with my daughter as possible and that has helped.  Friends have offered their time to help out  again with the housework post op and that has kept me going too as I know i am not fighting this alone - and the best bit is I know I am fighting it for the best reason - my 6 year old!   I do hope you have not got an infection and the latest trip to hospital to close the wound had worked.  and i hope your husband can talk about it with you.   I think breast cancer is like being put on a fast moving roller coaster, one minute you are plunged down with bad news, feeling awful the next rushed to a high point when good news or something life affirming happens.  there is not much straight run at the moment but that will get better - see the thread one year on from diagnosis day.... the very best wishes to you mum of two, i really really hope that you start healing well soon.   big hugs xx

Posts.Content: Horrendous decision to have to make I feel for you completely. In my case a mx meant that the percentage point benefits of chemo v tamoxifen were only 2 percent difference in chemos favour but that had to be weighed up against how I would tolerate and cope wigh the chemo for 6 months and then recovery after that. My medical team recommended tamoxifen and I wonder if my social situation swayed their recommendation as I am a lone parent so coping with u months of chemotherapy would have been v v tough. So I am hoping and praying that its the right choice. V emotional about it still lots of tears but I am more or less back to normal whatever that is, and if I was on chemo well I would be only half way through. I guess in a way having an er tumour has meant I got a choice when other patients dont get one. I also met a lovely lady who said no to the tamoxifen following her treatment as the predictor computer showed only a 2 percent advantage she weighed up the potential effect on her quality of life as her immediate health was v important to her. Wishing you and everyone who has to decide the awful to think about options the very very best. Blessings x
Posts.Title: anybody decide not to have chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi loopylou  if there is one thing I have learnt from this site is that everyons treatment is different.    I only had a small tumour  so thoughtwle would be the treatment but it wasn't enough and I had to have a mx   even though tumour only 2.8 cm and lymph clear   I wasn't offered any thing else and I have only come across one lady who had the same as me.  So take heart thst they are treating you as an individual  and ask your medical team lots of questions.   I was 49 and premenopausal too  so now on tamoxifen post surgery.      All the best  x
Posts.Title: tamoxifen to shrink tumour pre surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Isabella, Hi Purdy agree with you both, feels like a roller coaster!  Diagnosed at Easter and feet have barely touched the ground since. Also took along a long list of questions and a friend who asked the ones I forgot as sometimes it's all too much when you are sat face to face with the surgeon.  Been to the plastic surgeon by myself  twice though and took along questions - the nurses and surgeons have been great and i have never felt rushed and they answered all my questions and gave me a phone number to call if I had any more when I got home.  It's hard to make the decision regarding WLI or mastectomy, i can understand how you feel,  I felt the same when presented with all the options for the reconstruction, I called Macmillan and my breast care nurse and talked it over with close friends and that helped me decide.  My mastectomy will be in a couple of weeks - date to be confirmed next week.  Not heard of Cancer Connections, sounds helpful.  Have rang MacMillan a couple of times (once in tears) and they have been great and I rang my breast care nurse yesterday and she was very helpful and comforting. I feel for all posters who have had to tell their children, telling my daughter was the hardest part of it, but keeping positive for her is a huge blessing for which I am very grateful as I have found bits of strength I never knew I had!! good luck everyone  x

Posts.Title: Totally new and clueless

Posts.Content: Hi speeech you have certainly had a lot to deal with, amazing that something as horrid as the infectionn has actually done some good stopping the cancer from spreading. You are not at all vain asking for a reconstruction, like Wendy says everyone is entitled to the surgery. There are a bewildering number of options and some not possible depending on your physical make up, my bmi was too low for one type for example. It could be that the surgeon didn't mention it YET as u have had so much to deal with up till now. You should havd been given a contact number for the specialist plastic surgery nurse, give her a call and ask away! Mine was great and answered all the questions I was too shy to ask the male surgeon! Best of luck speech let us know how you get on. X Ps ignore fhe stupid shallow comments from collegue s its not freaky, its a war wound, a badge of bravery! Xx
Posts.Title: Reconstruction after a conservation surgery

Posts.Content: 2nd part as hit the wrong button! I jusr felt awful all the rime I was back at work part rime and not ccoping at home as I was too tired from work! So I started telling my friends and family and they were understand img and a few offers ofhelp rresurfaced. I also went back ro my medical team about the pain and side effects. I feel that rhe surgery was the doctors battling with rhe cancer but living after and not letting it take over my life, is where I srart fighting. Have you got a Maggie's near you? I have had sooooo much help and support from them since February its made all the difference. They offer complementary therapy for hot flushes etc and have relaxation sessions which really do help u feel better able to cope. Really hope you can do a phased return to work, get support at home lined up as u will be v tired, and some help with the hot flushes and night sweats and pain. Good luck too geeraf for your return to school, I work with preschool ers its exhausting! Don't suffer in silence speak out, get help and support, be kind to yourself, you are worth it. X x x
Posts.Title: Back to work next week

Posts.Content: Dear sixpence sorry to hear how you are feeling, I empathize with you and geeraf, people do indeed think cos u up and about everything must be ok now. It takes a long time for our emotions to recover from the appalling stress of the diagnosis, surgery, medicines, lack of sleep, pain, all of which are exhausting. On top of that we have to cope at home and manage other people's expectations. We deserve a medal! I too got fed up with people telling me how well I looked when I was actually exhausted and every movement was agony. I began to feel guilty if I said how I really felt as I could see I was expect ed to say Fine when I should have said I am worn out, in constant pain and could burst into tears any minute! Then things came to a head in feb 8 months post mx 8 months on tamoxifen and I realized I HAVE to be honest to myself and others and so

Posts.Title: cud it be bk ?

Posts.Content: Hi lizane how r you feeling today? I had tingling etc for some time after my mx and recin and still get it if I have been using my arm a lot. Trying to balance exercises with increasing mobility is tricky and frustrating when I just want to get on and do stuff! My bc team said it was all part of the process and the' its early days' arrrgghhh! But they r right however maddening at times! I had a huge seroma covering the left side of my back and extending to the side. It was painful as the skin was pulled so taut and it was difficult to get comfy with big lump! I took a soft cushion out with me everywhere even on the bus, and that helped. I did not have it drained, I just couldn't face anymore needles or procedure s and my plastics team said if u have it drained it will just keep refilling. I massaged it every day snd it did go on its own took about two months. I had to have it checked a few times to make sure it was going down. I sm pleased I let it alone but some women prefer to hsve them drained. Gd luck with your recovery. X
